review_title: Big Company, Powerful Brands (for better or for worse)
pros: Overall a great place to work. Creative, enthusiastic, fun. For the most part I'm really proud to work here.
cons: Bureaucracy, groupthink. Some systems, born out of necessity for a large company, could be revised. The company is also headed in the wrong direction culturally (although not as quickly as many other entertainment companies).

pros: A group of extremely smart, collaborative people
cons: Legacy issues between departments create rifts. Current management is an old boys club where most of the major positions are made up of middle age white guys. Locker room attitude and atmosphere when limited to this.

pros: Everyone is super friendly and knows how to have fun making people smile. Disney is truly a magical place to work.
cons: The scheduling for shifts is a little strange, such as call-in shifts which should be considered as regular shifts unless you call a few hours before and are told they do not need you.

job_title: Bus Driver in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: Fun place to work for, great place for advancement and move up in the company, many perks you receive even if you're part time or seasonal, transferring to different departments is very easy to do, easy to move to full time status.
cons: Pay rate is medium considering the company makes huge profits, working outside is very hard and for the people who work outside they should have more breaks in my opinion.

review_title: Good brand and practices...not so great in India yet.
pros: Again good brand, fair employment practices, lot of talented folks work here. If you get to work on core Disney brands in any of the division then go ahead and join
cons: Not core Disney culture....its a hodgepodge of acquisitions which havent been allowed to integrate properly. Left hand doesnt know what the right hand is doing and both dont care

pros: Second run with the Walt Disney Company (one in Parks, this one as in Intern in Corporate). The amount of trust your fellow coworkers will have on you will inspire you to perform. In addition, the learning experiences at this company are incomparable.
cons: The amount of work may deserve a better hourly wage, but the amount of experience you get as an Intern at Disney to use for the rest of your educational career completely outweigh this con.

review_title: Could be great, depending on your manager
pros:
Great IP and brands to work with
Decent pay
Park passes!
Great to have on your resume
If you have a good manager, you could be very successful, but there are some really bad managers to watch out for.
cons:
Very corporate & slow moving
Very political
Some terrible managers are allowed to wreak havoc because they BS the higher-ups

job_title: Deep Water Lifeguard in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros:
Great park admission and discount benefits.
Ability to move across the company laterally to many different roles.
cons:
Lacking good health insurance for Part Timers.
Hard to move up in the company even with many years experience.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Seattle, WA
pros:
Willing to experiment and adopt new technology
Good work/life balance
Family-friendly work environment
Diverse work force (sex, age, and race)
cons:
Opaque decision making
Communication between the top-level divisions is poor (Parks, Studios, ESPN, ABC, Interactive, International, etc)

job_title: Senior Product Manager in Glendale, CA
pros: Once you’re in, there’s a lot of opportunity to move around the larger organization (which you’ll want to do if you end up in DCPI)
cons: Re-orgs, leadership changes, cliquey culture, ugh. Tone-deaf leadership needs to get their priorities together! Remember - TWDC is an entertainment co. NOT a tech co. Soft skills outweigh actual execution 90/10.

job_title: User Experience Design Intern in Burbank, CA
pros:
You get to go to the Parks anytime for free
Employee events are fun since the culture is so open
Flexibility to work from home is great depending on your team culture.
cons:
They should invest more in other departments besides just ABC, Studios, or DCPI. Treat your corporate group better! 
Older folks tend to stay longterm so there's not much growth or opportunity movements.

review_title: Sexual Harassment was not handled or taken seriously!
job_title: Food and Beverage in Orlando, FL
pros: I was able to interact with a lot of people and got into the parks for free! I also met some of my best friends!
cons: I was sexually harassed by a chef and after reporting it multiple times, nothing was taken care of and I was stuck working with him every day. I ended up having to quit because of the lack of safety.

pros: 9pm off time, casual clothes, free Disney pass, and awesome coworkers
cons: Guest are rude, leaders are not helpful, management doesn’t know what they are doing, awful work space, no support, and always feeling like you are doing something wrong.

review_title: Great environment to work in. Hit or miss managers
pros: Extremely flexible and fun. Available sick time and grievance pay. Amazing 401k matching program for even part time castmembers
cons: Managers are a hit and miss. Some are very competent and go out of their way to make sure everyone is doing well. Some fall very behind on even walking out their office door only to come greet you with a half smile and complain about something or never respond to your concerns or requests.

job_title: Senior Programmer Analyst in Orlando, FL
pros: Great benefits, good work hours.
cons: Little room to grow, only if someone leaves may a possibility of promotion occur... It's like the fire department know one leaves. That may be good for some, but I am feeling un challenged.

review_title: A wonderfully creative and exciting environment to work in
pros: We make great family entertainment that I am proud to be a part of.  Commitment to delivering on expectations of our guests and customers drives our direction.
cons: When your the best its harder to stay on top...long days and sometimes longer weeks.

review_title: My experioence at disney was not so good yet not so bad.
pros: Best reasons to work at disney is all of the dicounts you can get, how well it looks on your resume, free park enteree and passes.
cons: Depending on your location you MUST work outside in the heat with only one water bottle and no refills for atleast 8 hours. You can get fired for POINTING the non-disney way. They do not value regular cast members and treat you like another number.

review_title: Good place if you like the corporate culture
pros:
Perks -- free entrance to parks & resorts, discounts on merchandise
Great brand to have on your resume
Interesting work
Recognized by everyone
cons:
Definitely a very corporate environment (a con if you dislike that)
As with any organization, politics between divisions can slow progress
The great brand can limit the company's ability to take big risks in certain areas

review_title: Disneyland was the ideal job for working during my college years.
pros: The friends I made at Disneyland are one of the biggest benefits of working at Disneyland. Also, they worked around school schedules great.
cons: The only downside of working at Disneyland was working the holidays, but then again, everyone was in the same boat. So at least you were working with friends!

review_title: Stay away from Walt Disney Parks & Resorts Online
pros: Good pay, great benefits and perks (free theme parks access, backstage tours, etc.), talented employees
cons: The leadership at Walt Disney Parks & Resorts Online (WDPRO) is the worst I've ever experienced. They are unorganized, egotistical, hypocritical, and out of touch. They've created a a toxic environment where everything is urgent and critical and subject to change at their whim. They have no concept of work-life balance. They firmly believe that everything will work out if they can just whip all of us moronic employees into delivering their grand visions.

pros: Stimulating environment that challenges you to be the best. Having the opportunity to work in the entertainment industry and represent the #1 brand in family entertainment is tons of fun. Great company perks and pension plan.
cons: You have to roll with the punches. The one thing that is constant is change and you must not only welcome it but embrace it to succeed.

pros: Great company benefits and wonderful employee perks. The company is one of the few companies still offering full educational assistance to its employees and even offers scholarships to the children of the employees
cons: Slow in promotion only because there are so many people in the company. The key is to look for the opportunities within the company yourself.

job_title: Working Lead Food & Beverage in Anaheim, CA
pros: Disney is an unbelievable company when it comes to guest service and providing nothing short of the very best service for them. They will give you top notch training and the rest is up to you. You pretty much get what you put in.
cons: A lot of young people work here so it can feel like high school.

pros:
- Comp package slightly above industry average
- Nice benefits/perks, including three weeks PTO, free entry to Disneyland/Disney World, 50% of Disney resorts and cruises, maternity/paternity leave
- Passionate co-workers who truly care about the company, and view Disney as their dream job
cons:
- The sheer size of the company can make employees feel like expendable cogs in a huge machine
- Hard to fit in if you don't drink the Disney Kool-Aid
- Employer match on 401(k) is weak compared to competitors

pros: The culture at Disney is spot on. Everyone is very friendly when you engage with them first.
cons: There is a clear distinction between FTE's and Contractors. Most people in the office do not go out of their way to say hi or get to know you unless you engage first.

review_title: Nice company, friendly staff, good benefits
pros: It's Disney! Nice people and a friendly working environment. The company is doing well and it is a good thing to be part of.
cons: there is not much to report on the downsides. The office space could be better as it is not the most modern or inspiring for such a creative business.

pros: Silver pass to visit Disneyland, excellent benefits & challenging projects
cons: Management changes directions at the drop of a hat with little transparency for those lower on the totem pole, and if you're not at a main hub office you can forget about feeling like part of the company as a whole - you'll get invites to happy hours that are half a state away.

pros: The company has some really extremely talented and passionate employees. Benefits are great.
cons: Depends on the division of the company but upward movement of career is hard to get unless you land in a division that makes lots of revenue

pros: Coming to work every day to contribute to a guest’s experience is a reward. My fellow cast members were happy and hard working.
cons: You must be very punctual and confirm to the Disney look. If you like to dye your hair non-traditional colors or insist to wear facial piercings, you will find this hard.

review_title: Lack of direction - an internal mess
job_title: Senior Account Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The people within Disney are some of the best, hardest working people I have ever met. The perks of Disney are great and it was a great experience.
cons: However, internally everything is a mess. They will have layoffs with notice of a new direction, but months before that new direction is messaged. Months of employees in limbo. It makes for terrible morale, which is seemingly completely ignored by upper management. There is little to no transparency

job_title: Manager of Operations in New York, NY
pros: Perks; free movie screenings, invitations to events
cons: Senior Management does not care or support middle/lower management

review_title: Disney Magic for some...but not for all.
pros: A good ethos, good benefits such as premieres, screenings, Disney passes and discounts
cons: No internal room for manouvre, lack of support and opportunities. The company is doing well financially but has not rewarded pay rises and does not hold a Christmas party an longer.

pros: Disney creates a very magical atmosphere for their employees to work. They have many ways to encourage their employees to get connected and allow for advancement when the time is right.
cons: Making working at Disney a sole way to provide for a family is very difficult. The workplace is very political. It's not what you know it's who you know that sometimes makes the difference.

job_title: Finance Analyst in Lake Buena Vista, FL
pros: The  operations training and financial systems training is incredible.  The cast members are there to support each other.  New software packages are always being rolled out so you learn the most up to date software.
cons: Terrible compensation that can not be put in words.   There is no such thing as work life balance and if you dare leave, do not ever plan on going back, even 20 years later.

pros: Lots of perks like screenings, Silver Pass, etc.
cons: Fun company, but lots of silos and tribal politics overall. Challenging to work across departmental lines. Lastly, everything is always done by committee or consensus or through external consultants (e.g. Accenture, PWCC, etc.). Few things are adopted top down or bottom up.

pros: Fast-paced, talented staff, well-equipped, forward thinking, good work-life balance, great benefits, beautiful campus, access to various other segments of Disney
cons: Limited to no long-term profitability goals centered around content, layoffs are usually every 6 months, poorly funded teams and business groups, "synergy" projects are unbalanced, work environment is sterile, little to no room for promotions, limited number of creative executive staff

pros: Talented people, some of the best, good office culture.  Employees are mostly well-compensated. There are worse places you could work.
cons: Lack of creativity, surprisingly. Leadership changes every few year or two to chase profitability and they close down a studio they bought not long before.  Making a quality product is much further down the list.  Chasing trends and replicating rather than taking a small risk on originality.

review_title: A fun job that is unfortunately ending due to budget cuts
pros: The chance to represent a world-wide respected brand as The Walt Disney Company on a local level was an experience I couldn't have found anywhere else.
cons: Lots of weekend work.  Long hours.  Struggle keeping sales team.  Some work locations would be hours away throughout Michigan or Ohio.

pros: Great team. Fun work environment. Very creative projects and people to work with. Team oriented projects that allow you to see multiple departments work together at once.
cons: Haven't had major problems. Seems the problems that were there were taken care of before I started. Really great people, can't complain

pros:
- Great perks (ie. Silver Pass and Disney discounts)
- Disney, especially Parks & Resorts, ESPN have been performing extraordinarily well over the past few years.
cons:
- Large company so culture varies from team-to-team
- Can be very political - need to know and befriend the right people

pros: Working with glimpses of creative brilliance. Working on the lot is like being in another world. There is everything you need from the commissary to Starbucks to dry-cleaning in the employee store.
cons: The red tape is unbearable and the meetings for no reason are never ending. The new CFO lacks confidence in the people she works with and this will affect people adversely.

pros:
The recognition they give their employees is amazing. 
The experience to work for Disney
You work hard to make you location goals and have fun too.
Guest Relations is awesome, you meet people from all over the world that come to NYC for the first time and you have a chance to guide them in your own city. You also get a chance to learn different languages with guests.
cons: The salary is low,but you get a small raise every year.

pros: Strong brand and reputation. If you can work here, you can work anywhere. Lots of learning opportunities. Movement between departments has improved. Good variety of responsibilities.
cons: Growth and promotions are very hard to receive. At times feel like just a number within the organization. Many layoffs constantly occurring throughout the company.

review_title: A media company not a tech company
pros: Fun people to work with. You will rarely encounter a team in which you do not get along with everyone.
cons: Micro management from Executive leadership interferes with solution planing causing short term fixes that do not address the long term issues or needs of the company. It is not uncommon to see the same issue repeat month after month.  If you are well versed in ITIL do not expect to see it well executed here.

pros: The people you work with on a daily basis. The people are extremely smart and talented however everyone's hands are tied by strict budgets and rushed deadlines.
cons: Shady, deceitful, non-appreciative & underhanded leadership makes this job unbearable at times. Work load is not on par with the salary, be prepared to work long work days/nights and weekends to meet the companies unrealistic deadlines.

job_title: Grand Gatherings Travel/Reservation Agent in Orlando, FL
pros: The atmosphere at Disney World is joyous and full of diversity.  This past employer tops my list of favorite places to work.
cons: Some positions are expendable especially if the expected quotas aren't being met. The communication required to avoid a separation of employment should be more evident.

pros: great teams to work within, fun atmosphere, challenging work provided, cool brands to work with.  Get to work with other countries and departments

review_title: Don’t do it, it’s a trap

pros: Potential opportunity to grow within, Certain Disney Perks

review_title: Politics and Egos Run Amuck in the Mouse House

review_title: Super Cool Media Company with focus on People, Technology and Processes

cons: No much to say here

pros: Great benefits/discounts/perks for Disney experiences.  Brand name Company is a resume booster.  Many smart and talented co-workers.

review_title: Highly political but top tier brand
pros: Great brand name on your resume, and a good place to get exposed to all aspects of business.  So many different divisions that you can keep moving around to expand your skill set and get promoted
cons: Half of mental energy goes to managing the politics, other half to the actual job at hand

review_title: overall a fun but not financially lucrative experience
pros: It was a fun job with great perks for employees. My co-workers were fantastic and the management wasn't too bad either.

review_title: Working and working at Disney ABC Television.

Great perks and health benefits.

There are too many hands on a single project.

review_title: Depends who you work for/what projects you work in

review_title: One of the best companies to work for!

review_title: The guest service experience is quite remarkable.

review_title: Disney Parks & Resorts Digital is a great place to work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Ciudad de Mexico

pros: I enjoyed working with the Walt Disney company as a way to give back. I very much appreciated the chance to create my own little version of magic for the children, parents, familys, and everyone else that came in to the store.

pros: Off on all major holidays, the hours are decent, and you get to go to all the theme parks

pros: Fun. Pixie dust. Magical place. Disney University is great training. Very professional. But...

pros: Great benefits, and perks of the job - including getting advanced screenings, and of course meeting Mickey Mouse! Everyone within the offices is welcoming, and very out going.

pros: The company takes where you want to work into consideration. There are plenty of opportunity so that you do not get bored. Coming from attractions point of view, one day i oculd work a ride, the next a special event, the next guest control.

review_title: I am very hard working and will do anything for the company.

pros: enjoyed my time there, although glass door only lets me post back to 2014 and it has been a couple of decades since I was there

Motivating to do well.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in North Hollywood, CA

pros: Excellent image to employees from benefits for family and hard-work, inspiring to be part of a creative team, Cohesiveness, team-building a must, benefits, theme park access. Always great to hear reactions from people who know you work for Disney.Great proximity to valley and westside.
cons: Turnover, senior management changes, direction of video business, vs. theatrical.  Current management and acquisitions of Marvel and LucasFilm create new opportunities, but some may lose jobs.

pros: Recognizable company, safe work environment

job_title: Production Assistant in North Tarrytown, NY

cons: When I interned (2011) the per diem sucked. Otherwise.. none that I can think of.

pros: Theme park admission and merchandise discounts.  Experience lots of different cultures.  Seeing the smile on babies faces.

review_title: Great opportunities and location, fulfill your dreams

review_title: It's a good company to add some weight to your career and resume, but I am not sure if it is a place to stay for long.

pros: Great middle management and lots of opportunity to learn the ins and outs of a reputable entertainment company.  "Disney" opens the doors for many different jobs in the future, even if it's not within the Disney company...

job_title: Director, Accounting and Finance in Burbank, CA

cons: Like most companies these days, there are business areas the take advantage of their salaried employees, making then work 60-80 hour weeks without paying them overtime.

review_title: Underpaid with no opportunity for growth
pros: The people who work for Disney are all very bright, intelligent, and friendly people. It's a nice environment. Additionally, the benefits and perks are fantastic - even more so if you're a Disney fan. It's a great IP to work with. There's something exciting about working for a company such as Disney with such a long-standing tradition of quality entertainment.
cons: Sadly Disney Interactive is struggling to make ends meet. There is very little opportunity for career growth and salaries to typically far below fair market value.

review_title: A good place to work overall.
pros: Good benefits and reasonable pay.  A challenging work environment.
cons: No work/life balance.  This place eats managers for lunch so the vision/plan at the group level is always changing.  The review system is just a box to be checked by the managers.

review_title: Not The Happiest Place On Earth

pros: benefits, state of the art building and services, a wonder VP of global communication, Kevin Brokman

review_title: It all depends on which department you work in.
pros: As one lady says in my department:  The checks don't bounce.

If you're lucky you might land in one of the departments that is considered "important" and glamorous."  Those departments get the necessary budgets for a proper staff, promotions, etc.  If you don't land in one of those departments you're in for a challenging time.  it can be a very arrogant company with an attitude of "you're lucky to have a job at a great company like this."

Here are a few things I've witnessed on the job:  

The head of my department having a stroke -- as in literal medical stroke -- right in front of my eyes.  Her face turned white with blotches of red, she froze in place and couldn't talk or move for several minutes.  This was from the overall stress.

A manager collapsing to the ground, people were afraid she had a heart attack.  An ambulance was called, she was carried out on a stretcher.  Again, this turned out to be a manifestation of stress.

Management level folks getting into a "slamming doors" war because one manager was given a more glamorous project.  One door would slam, then the other manager would slam his door even louder in retaliation, etc.  This was a common occurrence.

There was the time I broke up a fist fight between a manager and a director level employee who got into an argument.

A lot of weird office politics -- promotions going to the worst possible employees who rarely -- if ever -- came into work but of course they happened to be good friends with the right people.

Again, though, you might get lucky and land in one of the "important" departments that have a proper budget and staff where tensions don't run as high.

pros: Working with the guests was fantastic. When I started at Disney, I was able to make wonderful experiences for guests who were visiting. The things you could do for guests in the park were truly amazing until 2009.
cons:
After the Monorail wreck, Disney did not back up the Cast Members of that department. They did not provide proper services or follow-up to make sure that the people who had experienced a tragedy at work were getting the care they needed. That, on top of being in a position where you were making close to minimum wage while having so much responsibility just did not work well. The company began making changes property-wide that appear on paper to increase the safety of the areas, but in reality they do little to take care of the most important aspect of safety: a mindset. Rules do not create safety the way a safety mindset does. The company wants to be able to put anyone into the role for which you take great pride in operating safely, and in the end you realize they think they could train a monkey to do your job.

I know people who still work at Disney, in safety-related roles. Specifically, I know several people who are Lake Patrol lifeguards in several areas. There is no consistency from one area to the next. On one lake, if they hear from a trusted source that lightning is close enough to be dangerous, they will shut down the lake. On another lake, they at least trust the Lake Patrol employees enough that they can call out how many seconds away they see a lightning strike, and that is taken under advisement. In one area, if an employee who is not a supervisor calls a count, they can face punishment. My spouse works on this lake where punishment can be doled out for trying to contribute to the safety of employees and customers, and she works in the Lake Patrol position; she is on a boat, on the lake. Every day during the summer, I have that nagging question in the back of my head: Will my wife be allowed to make it off the water today before lightning strikes? Will she come home? Having already been in a situation where a coworker was killed, I guess this reality is much more real to me than it is the managers.

Safety is whatever the local manager says it is, despite what the operating guidelines say. One week an activity can be acceptable; the next it is a firing offense; the next week it is acceptable again.

review_title: Must Be Part of the In-crowd
pros:
- If you love Disney as a brand, that makes the cons a tad bit (and I mean a TAD) easier to deal with.
- You get to hear about upcoming products/movies before anyone else (that's kind of cool).
cons:
- Disney is an entertainment company so it comes with schmoozing, the typical "who you know defines your importance", and brown-nosing is the ONLY way you'll get promoted (forget hard work/talent/experience, that stuff doesn't work here).
- They talk a lot about work/life balance and professional development but there's absolutely zero action behind it. Leadership says that they encourage you to keep a good work/life balance - but then they turn around and expect you to respond to emails and complete projects 24/7 (and yes you're required to do so). 
- You are 100% on your own - so if you don't do well with figuring everything out on your own (from where the commissary is to how to do your job) - then this isn't the place for you.
- No such thing as leadership here. They're too busy schmoozing and doing everything they can to fulfill their own personal agenda - so don't expect to find anyone that you can lean into or learn from.
- They boast a collaborative environment but only those that matter have good ideas - so if you're not part of the "in-crowd", don't even bother. If you do speak up, be prepared for your idea/suggestion to be either a) taken with zero credit to you or b) taken then scrutinized (as will you for even coming up with the idea; think Mean Girls to the 100th power).
- And if you're wondering, the "in-crowd" consists of a group of inexperienced millennial-bots that only say yes and wing everything they do (because inexperience is key!).

Overall, people work here because they love the brand NOT because of the professional growth/recognition/collaborative team environment/leadership support. If you're a big Disney fan, just be prepared to see all that goes on behind the magic. All of the good, the bad, and the really ugly of what Disney is as a corporate company. The corporate conservative dark under belly of Disney will change your view of their products so just be prepared to see it, experience it, and deal with it.
